children.title: animals
children.comment: A category of living creatures that dwell mainly on the land, distinguished from fishes, birds and insects. Scripture stresses that all animals are created by God and are subordinate to human beings.

children.title: animals, nature of
children.comment: As a class within the created order, their variety reflects God's generous giving. He makes human beings their stewards, though they themselves come into the category of creatures.

children.title: Animals as illustrated by their variety
Human beings within the animal creation
Significantly different from the rest of creation
Human beings as stewards of the animal kingdom
Animals as the objects of divine, and therefore human, care
animals, religious role of
children.comment: Central to the OT sacrificial system, they were governed by strict laws within the Mosaic code.

children.title: Animals as defined by the Law of Moses
Animals in the context of Israel's sacrificial system
Animals in the context of judgment
animals, nature of
children.comment: As a class within the created order, their variety reflects God's generous giving. He makes human beings their stewards, though they themselves come into the category of creatures.

children.title: Animals as illustrated by their variety
Human beings within the animal creation
Significantly different from the rest of creation
Human beings as stewards of the animal kingdom
Animals as the objects of divine, and therefore human, care
animals, religious role of
children.comment: Central to the OT sacrificial system, they were governed by strict laws within the Mosaic code.

children.title: Animals as defined by the Law of Moses
Animals in the context of Israel's sacrificial system
Animals in the context of judgment
beast, the
children.comment: In apocalyptic literature, symbol of the ultimate adversary of God in the great final spiritual battle.

cschildren.title: Beasts represent rulers and nations opposed to God
The beast represents the antichrist in the final spiritual battle

children.title: The power and authority of the beast
Those who will worship the beast, and those who will not
The defeat of the beast and the fulfilment of God's purposes
birds
children.comment: Part of the created world, used for food. In OT times they were also used in sacrifices. In Scripture, birds are used in many metaphors.

children.title: To be cared for by humanity

cschildren.title: Not to be used as an object of worship

children.title: bull
children.comment: Bulls were particularly prized as sacrifices on account of their considerable value. The sacrifice of a bull was especially associated with the sin offering.

children.title: Instructions for the offering of a bull
Godly sacrifices in contrast to pagan ones

cschildren.title: Even the sacrifice of bulls invalid without the spiritual conditions being fulfilled
Provisional nature of the OT sin offering of a bull
The bull as a symbol of strength
Bulls in the design of the temple
Bulls in the setting of judgment

children.title: calf
children.comment: A young animal prized as the source of tender meat, suitable for celebrations. However, it also had associations with both the OT sacrificial system and idolatry.

cschildren.title: The association of the calf with idolatry
The flesh of the calf as a prized food

children.title: colt
children.comment: A young, untrained horse or donkey, associated in Scripture with humility or peace.

cschildren.title: A colt is a young donkey
The use of a colt by the coming king

children.title: cow
children.comment: Cows, in OT times, often symbolised wealth and material well-being.

primaryrefs.comment: Part of Job's complaint about the prosperity of the wicked.

seealsos.comment: the believer's joy despite the absence of prosperity

cschildren.title: Cows as a source of nourishment and fuel

children.title: creatures
children.comment: Generally, living beings within God's creation, especially the exotic animals seen in visions, which often have a deep symbolic significance.

cschildren.title: Creatures representing angelic beings who worship God

primaryrefs.comment: The strange creatures of Ezekiel and Revelation seem to stand for the fulness and variety of God's creation.

seealsos.comment: The creatures are here identified as cherubim

primaryrefs.comment: The ``beasts'' here are unnatural, and represent the hostility of human empires to the rule of God. The horns represent individual kings within an imperial dynasty.

cschildren.title: Creatures representing Satan
cschildren.precomment: The beast here represents Satan, with the horns representing royal authority at a time of Roman persecution of the church:

children.title: dog
children.comment: Although used by shepherds and occasionally kept as pets, in Bible times most dogs were semi-wild scavengers.

cschildren.title: Dogs in the teaching of Jesus Christ
Dogs used as a term of abuse or low esteem

children.title: donkey
children.comment: A beast of burden, used to carry both goods and people.

seealsos.comment: As beasts of burden they were afforded rest on the Sabbath.

children.title: dove
children.comment: A common species of bird. In Scripture the dove symbolises the Spirit of God, and also certain kinds of human behaviour.

cschildren.title: Doves as sacrifices for those who were poor
The dove as a symbol of the Spirit of God

children.title: fish
children.comment: A basic ingredient of diet in biblical times. Fishing was regarded as a trade rather than a recreation.

cschildren.title: Fish as part of God's creation
Fish as the object of pagan worship

children.title: Fish as a symbol of entrapment
Fish as a symbol of the kingdom of God
Fish as a symbol of the resurrection

cschildren.title: The woolly covering of a sheep used as an article of clothing or for warmth
Used by Gideon for reassurance that he was doing God's will

children.title: goad
children.comment: A spike used to drive animals on. The term is also figuratively applied to prompting and guiding people into action.

cschildren.title: The goad as a farming implement
Goading as a symbol of discipline

seealsos.comment: The promptings of love and faith may be seen as symbolic goads.

children.title: goat
children.comment: A common animal used both for food and within the sacrificial system.

primaryrefs.comment: The tabernacle curtains were spun from goat hair, the ordinary material for making tents.

children.title: As a measure of wealth and payment
At the dedication of the temple

cschildren.title: The sacrifice of goats is unable to actually remove sins

secondaryrefs.comment: In spite of their many sacrifices there was no evidence of repentance

cschildren.title: Goats are symbolic of sinful humanity

children.title: horn
children.comment: The hard, pointed growth on the heads of certain animals; a projection resembling such a growth. The horns of animals were regarded as symbols of strength. In apocalyptic writings, horns may denote various powers and enemies of God. Altars were made with horn-like corner projections.

children.title: As projections at corners of altars
Symbolising the power of world rulers and enemies of God
Symbolising the power of Jesus Christ
horse
children.comment: The animal most commonly associated with war and battle, the horse also appears figuratively in poetic and prophetic literature. Its domesticated usage was mainly for personal travel and the haulage of heavy loads.

cschildren.title: Horses as a means of exchange and a measure of wealth
Horses as a means of transport and for the haulage of loads
The figurative and prophetic use of horse imagery

children.title: insects
children.comment: A wide variety of insects are mentioned in Scripture. Some are useful in the provision of food, while others are viciously destructive. Their behaviour is used figuratively in the poetic and prophetic literature.

children.title: The spider
children.precomment: Although not strictly an insect the spider is most conveniently included under this category:

children.title: lamb
children.comment: A common source of clothing and meat, this animal was given heightened significance by its place in the Jewish sacrificial system and was used figuratively of Jesus Christ.

children.title: The best had to be chosen
Describing Jesus Christ and his work
lion
children.comment: An important animal in the natural history of Palestine; a symbol of power and strength.

cschildren.title: Lions seen as a threat to life

children.title: Jesus Christ is likened to a lion
Satan is likened to a lion

cschildren.title: The lion in God's new creation

children.title: locust
children.comment: The most destructive of all biblical insects, also used figuratively as a devouring pest.

cschildren.title: There was no defence against locusts
Locusts were frequently a sign of God's judgment
Locusts were a source of food

children.title: manger
children.comment: A feeding trough in a stable or stall, filled with fodder for donkeys, oxen, etc. The term is also used to refer to the stall in which animals were kept. The newborn Jesus was laid in a manger because there was no room at an inn.

children.title: Recognised by the animals of the household

primaryrefs.comment: Israel is like a wild animal which does not recognise or accept God's provision.

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ laid in a manger
The nest as the home of a bird rearing its young
The nest as a place of security
The nest may not always be safe
The nest as the home of the viper

children.title: pigeon
children.comment: A bird used, along with doves, for sacrifices, especially by those who could not afford lambs.

cschildren.title: Pigeons offered as a sacrifice by the poor

children.title: ram
children.comment: The male sheep, part of an agrarian economy and used in sacrifice. Its skin had value and its horn was used in worship.

cschildren.title: Rams as part of an agrarian economy
Rams were used for religious purposes

children.title: In the making of a covenant

cschildren.title: The ram's skin brought as an offering for the construction of the tabernacle

children.title: sheep
children.comment: Sheep were a major feature of ancient Israel's rural economy. Although they were of importance as a source of food and wool, they also symbolise helplessness and the need for guidance.

children.title: As a measure of wealth and God's blessing
Sheep were used in striking a bargain
The care of sheep was a recognised occupation
The people that belong to God
Jesus Christ's care for his own
A picture of God's future blessings
snake
children.comment: A reptile, often associated with cunning and danger, or occasionally with satanic temptation.

children.title: Both to animals and human beings
They were sometimes used to bring God's judgment
One day they will be rendered harmless
wings
children.comment: Limbs which enable flight. In Scripture these are mainly used either of angelic beings or in various symbolic senses, especially of God's protection.

cschildren.title: Wings as a metaphor of protection

children.title: God's protection likened to a bird's wings
Egypt's protection likened to an eagle's wings

secondaryrefs.comment: Zedekiah's fruitless appeal to Egypt for help against Babylon

cschildren.title: Wings as a metaphor for God's judgment

children.title: God rides on the wings of the wind
Israel described as a winged bird
Wings symbolise the ability to escape

secondaryrefs.comment: God is likened to the rays of the sun.

children.title: yoke
children.comment: The wooden collar which joins two animals, usually oxen, to enable them to pull together. Used metaphorically the term may denote the partnership of those who share a yoke or, more usually, the subjection of those under a yoke. As his covenant partners God's people are yoked to him and he will break the oppressive yoke of their enemies.

cschildren.title: The yoke as a symbol of partnership

secondaryrefs.comment: too close association with the immoral

cschildren.title: The yoke as a symbol of subjection

children.title: Israel under the yoke of enemies

primaryrefs.comment: Jeremiah symbolically portrays the coming Babylonian exile.

secondaryrefs.comment: Esau will throw off the yoke of Jacob.
Slaves are to respect their masters.

children.title: God breaks the yoke of oppression
